title: Police investigate suspected antisemitic firebombing in St Kilda | ABC NEWS
description: Police are investigating the apparent firebombing of a vehicle with a Hanukkah decoration in Melbourne's south-east early on Christmas Day.  Emergency services arrived in Balaclava Road, St Kilda East at about 2:50am to find the vehicle on fire. title: 20 Biggest Stories of '25 - Part Five
description: Unbox what we've picked as the four biggest Australian sports stories of 2025. Including a massive Australian at the centre of arguably the biggest sports event of the year, a homophobic scandal in the AFL, an Aussie coach charting new territory on the world stage, as well as a historic and bitter rivalry delivering a surprising new chapter.¬†   Subscribe to the ABC Sport Newsletter (https://www.abc.net.au/connect)

title: Boddington residents urged to evacuate immediately as bushfire approaches | ABC NEWS
description: Residents of Boddington, southeast of Perth have been told to evacuate immediately. The fire which started near the Boddington gold mine remains at emergency level after heatwave conditions and gusty winds caused the fire to rapidly spread on Christmas day. title: Sarah Ferguson on interviewing Jacinda Ardern | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Sarah Ferguson's interviews illuminate the biggest issues of our times and reveal insights from the most interesting people in public life.   How did she stop US ambassador to Israel Mike Huckabee from "flooding the zone" when grilling him on US support for Israel's war in Gaza? What did she learn about compassion in politics when speaking with New Zealand's former Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern?¬†   This week, Sam Hawley is joined by ABC presenters and journalists to discuss their best stories and interviews from 2025.   Today, Sarah Ferguson, host of ABC's 7.30 program, shares her insights from her big name interviews.

title: In 1999, what did Aussies think of mobile internet? | ABC NEWS
description: In 1999, mobile phones were on the cusp of the next technical revolution: internet in the palm of your hands! Customers were getting ready to conference on-the-go, send and receive faxes, and use a special miniature keyboard to type up an email.  From the ABC archive. Social version by Madeleine Wales for ABC News Digital.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Severe storm causes crane to partially collapse on the Gold Coast | ABC NEWS
description: Police have set up an exclusion zone on the Gold Coast after a severe storm caused a crane to partially collapse.  Emergency services were called to the Gold Coast Highway at Southport at 3:15pm on Thursday following reports of a crane and multiple powerlines being damaged in the area. title: How to spot dodgy deals and scams this Boxing Day | ABC NEWS
description: Australians have lost millions to shopping scams this year, prompting the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and consumer advocates to urge shoppers to watch out for dodgy deals and online scams. Gary Mortimer, a retail marketing professor at Queensland University of Technology, warns about rogue retailers who inflate prices before Boxing Day sales and 'ghost stores' that appear online.  To stay safe, he suggests Googling the names of online retailers to verify their physical presence, checking customer testimonials and reviewing ratings on Trustpilot. title: King Charles pays homage to acts of 'spontaneous bravery' | ABC NEWS
description: King Charles III has paid tribute to community members who demonstrated "spontaneous bravery" in his annual Christmas message, recognising people who put "themselves in harm's way to defend others", like those who confronted terror at Bondi. The address was filmed at Westminster Abbey with a theme of 'pilgrims of hope' and watched by millions of people around the world. In his message, King Charles urged people of different faiths to find common ground and stressed the need for tolerance, saying the strength of modern societies lies in the diversity of their people.
